metadata.case_name: Bansidhar Premsukhdas v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Former State of Bharatpur issued notification on May 18, 1946 (Ex.4) offering plots in Mandi for sale by public auction with terms including cl.3 granting 25% reduction in customs duty on certain commodities imported/exported, not available for vegetable Ghee.
Appellant purchased plots Nos. 8 and 9 for Rs. 4,600 at public auction; sale deeds issued on October 10, 1946.
Government of Bharatpur, then United State of Matsya, and thereafter Rajasthan State allowed 25% reduction in customs duty as per cl.3 until January 16, 1951.
Rajasthan Government issued notification No. F.4(18)SR/49 on January 16, 1951 abolishing all free Mandies and Zones, ceasing customs concessions with immediate effect.
Appellant and traders made representation on January 29, 1951; pending disposal, customs authorities kept 25% as Amanat.
Rajasthan Government decided on May 25, 1951 that reduction in customs duty could not be conceded.
Appellant filed suit on March 31, 1953 in District Judge, Bharatpur for recovery of Rs. 86,646/3/- being excess customs duty paid.
District Judge, Bharatpur decreed suit on March 31, 1956 holding cl.3 was term of sale and Rajasthan bound.

State appealed to Rajasthan High Court in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 29 of 1956; High Court allowed appeal, dismissed suit on January 29, 1963 holding cl.3 not part of contract and Rajasthan not bound.
Matsya Union formed on March 18, 1948; Matsya Customs Ordinance promulgated September 21, 1948.
United State of Rajasthan constituted May 15, 1949; Rajasthan Regulation of Customs Duties Ordinance No.16 of 1949 promulgated August 9, 1949 abolishing internal customs duties.

legal_issues.text: Whether cl. 3 of Bharatpur notification Ex.4 dated May 18, 1946 was a term of the contract of sale between appellant and State of Bharatpur.
Whether successor State of Rajasthan was bound by the contractual term in cl.3 assuming it was part of the contract.
Whether the contractual liability was superseded by subsequent ordinances like Rajasthan Regulation of Customs Duties Ordinance No.16 of 1949.

petitioner_arguments.text: Ex.4 notification was an offer to public which appellant accepted by purchasing plots, forming valid contract including cl.3 as term.
Implied recognition by Rajasthan State as exemptions continued up to January 13, 1951.
Notification dated January 16, 1951 revoking concessions violated Art.306 of Constitution.

respondent_arguments.text: Cl.3 concession did not relate to or form part of contract of sale of plots; benefits for trade in Mandi generally, not reciprocal promise for plot purchase.
Successor State not automatically bound; no recognition of contractual liability.
Certain conditions in notification (cls.5,6,7,10,11) cannot be terms of sale.

court_reasoning.text: Assumes cl.3 was term of contract in favour of appellant but holds suit fails as no recognition by successor Rajasthan State; contracts terminate with change of sovereignty unless ratified.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Successor State not subrogated ipso jure; recognition express or implied needed.

court_reasoning.text: Continuation of concessions referable to new laws/ordinances, not recognition of old contract; ordinances repealed prior customs laws without saving contractual rights.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rajasthan Regulation of Customs Duties Ordinance No.16/1949 repealed old tariffs and contracts.

court_reasoning.text: Even assuming recognition, contractual liability superseded by Ordinance No.16/1949; legislature competent to alter prior contracts absent constitutional prohibition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No saving clause in Ordinance for prior contracts.

court_reasoning.text: Art.306 not applicable as claim based on contract, not state levy under prior law; agreement with Centre satisfied conditions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Claim not under Bharatpur law but contractual.

holdings.text: Cl.3 assumed as contract term but no recognition by successor State; contract not enforceable.
Prior contracts repudiated by ordinances; legislature can supersede contracts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary of State in Council of India v. Kamachee Boye Saheba
precedents_cited.relevance: Act of State doctrine; municipal courts cannot question sovereign acts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India in Council
precedents_cited.relevance: Acquisition of territory is act of State; only recognized rights enforceable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary of State v. Sardar Rustom Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: New sovereign decides recognition of prior titles.

precedents_cited.case_name: M/s. Dalmia Dadri Cement Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle of act of State in mergers.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Saurashtra v. Jamadar Mohamat Abdulla
Maharaja Shree Umaid Mills Ltd. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Legislature can alter contracts; Art.295 no bar.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Gujarat v. Vora Fiddali Badruddin Mithibarwala
precedents_cited.relevance: Act of State in state formations.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thakur Jagannath Baksh Singh v. United Provinces
precedents_cited.relevance: Legislature competent to alter Crown grants.

precedents_cited.case_name: Maharaj Umeg Singh v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: No curtailment of legislative competence by merger guarantees.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Regulation of Customs Duties Ordinance No.16 of 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Abolished internal customs duties, repealed prior laws without saving contracts; superseded prior concessions.

statutes_cited.name: Matsya Customs Ordinance No.14 of 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed prior levies in Matsya Union; power to exempt or charge duties.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.306 allowed continuance of state border duties per agreement; no bar to legislation altering contracts.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding Rajasthan High Court decree dismissing appellant's suit for recovery of excess customs duty, holding no enforceable contract against successor State.

key_quotes.text: "The contractual liability of a former State is binding on a succeeding sovereign State only if it recognises that contractual liability."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle on successor states and contracts.

key_quotes.text: "It is not correct to say as a matter of law that the successor State automatically inherits the rights and obligations of the merged State."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "There is nothing in the provisions of the Rajasthan Regulation of Customs Duties Ordinance No. 16 of 1949 which preserves the alleged contractual rights of the appellant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
